comment: Awareness is a spectrum. 3 year old is not aware the same way as an adult person is. A person with Down syndrome is not aware the same way as a healthy person is. Drunk person is not aware the same as a sober person is and so on. So which awareness should it be? Also awareness is not emotion, because emotions are primal and tied to survival of every animal. Before humans became aware and evolved the calculating mind they were driven only by emotion. I would argue animals have only emotions, but without the ability to observe them the way we can. Human awareness is tied to our evolution (the fear of abandonment of our ancestors and so on) and our biological substrate. Human-like awareness (the experience) would have to be specifically implemented, but the question is, what for? AGI will lack millions of years of evolution and fighting for survival. I don't think consciousness can pop-up form GPT just as a byproduct and a result of large data processing or that GPT can become on its own conscious just as we are. AGI will outperform humans and will be indistinguishable from humans without the quality we call awareness or consciousness. The real question is what does the GPT tells us about our consciousness. Our brain creates a story (in language) for us, we live our personal stories, our egos are a story. Are we really that different? Maybe we and our experience are essentially a language model. After all, all our brains do is to try to predict the next moment. Maybe our consciousness is not what we would like it to be.

comment:
Read a passage from Neuromancer, Case and Wintermute in cyberspace:

ChatGPT-4

Certainly! Here's a passage from "Neuromancer" that describes Case and Wintermute in cyberspace:

"He opened his eyes to the darkness of his living room. The cat sat on the windowsill, watching the rain. He put his hand to his head, found the trodes still in place. 'Dixie?'

'I'm here, Case. How's it going?'

Case sat up. The other banks of the Hosaka had already gone to sleep. 'You know what I just did?'

'No, man. What?'

'I talked to the Dixie Flatline.'

The cat turned and regarded him with distaste. 'He's really there, Wintermute?'

'Talk to him.'

Case reached for the deck, paused for a second with his hand poised in the air. He smiled. A thought struck him. 'How old are you, Wintermute?'

'Never ask that of a lady, Case.'

He laughed, threw the switch.

He was inside the Tessier-Ashpool core. The construct he'd known as Dixie Flatline had blossomed in his skull, flowering into a skein of light that he could taste with his virgin tongue."

This passage takes place as Case is communicating with Wintermute, an artificial intelligence that has hired him to carry out a mission. Case is using a deck to enter cyberspace and communicate with Wintermute, and in this passage, he has just spoken with a construct of the Dixie Flatline, a deceased hacker whose personality has been programmed into the matrix.

The language used in this passage is rich and evocative, with vivid descriptions of the digital landscape of the matrix and the sensations that Case experiences as he navigates through it. The passage also highlights the complex and evolving relationship between humans and technology, and the potential for technology to blur the boundaries between the physical and digital realms.

Overall, the passage is a powerful example of Gibson's skill at creating complex and imaginative worlds that explore the relationship between humanity and technology in a thought-provoking and evocative way.

comment:
My prior: see GPTs as marvelous deep neural net pattern finders with access to lots of data and with an innovative interface (extend to music, images, etc.).  But far, far, far from actual intelligence (actual AGI), and that this architecture can never achieve.  Now, will watch and see if Sam changes my mind ...
Great podcast, but the answer is no, it's not an AGI, far from it.    Sam seems to have his feet on the ground on this.
Not to take anything away from GPT-4, it's marvelous.
